awd_titl_txt: A Tough Call: Understanding the Gendered Impact of Mobile Technology in Low Income Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
The increasingly powerful and decreasing cost of smartphones throughout the world is making it possible for low income communities to access the internet and social other media. How does this increased access to the internet and other forms of social media affect women’s participation in business and politics in these communities? This research will use experimental methods and modern economic theory to investigate the effects of internet access through smartphones on women’s business success and political participation in low income communities.  In addition, the research will investigate whether there are gender differences in adoption of this mobile technology, whether there are gender gaps in the effects of mobile technology on business development and political participation, especially whether access to the internet encourages women to run for political office.  Finally, the research will also study whether access to the internet changes gender norms in low income communities.  The results of this research will provide a better understanding of how technical innovation affect low income communities and whether these effects differ by gender.  It also provides inputs into designing policies to reduce poverty in low income communities. This research establishes the US as the global leader in the study of the effects digital technological innovation on low income communities.

This project encompasses two separate studies focusing on the effects of internet access through mobile phones on low income communities and their distributional consequences. Both parts leverage a sudden and large-scale availability of low cost smartphones to low income rural households. The PIs will use a regression discontinuity design to study how smart phone access impact electoral outcomes, political conflict, and women’s political engagement. The PIs will construct outcome variables from community-level data on electoral outcomes, including voter turnout by gender, performance of female candidates, and performance of candidates with criminal records. The project will also use newspaper reports to construct a geographically-explicit database of women’s political mobilization. In the second study, the project will employ a randomized controlled trial strategy that introduces a new value-added service for recently acquired mobile phones by women: the service delivers weekly information on health and government services, while contacting women on a monthly basis to solicit their feedback on service provision. The study will vary financial incentives to use the service as well as the share of women in the community invited to participate in the service. This design will allow the PIs to assess whether providing women with a norms-compatible “use case” for phones can spur deeper adoption, while quantifying how peer effects inform the adoption decision, and how adoption impacts social norms and women’s networks.  The results of this research will provide a better understanding of how technical innovation affect low income communities and whether these effects differ by gender.  This research establishes the US as the global leader in the study of the effects digital technological innovation on low income communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2020, Yale’s Economic Growth Center received funding from the National Sciences Foundation to accomplish three primary objectives through ongoing work in Chhattisgarh, India: 

  1. Digitize village-level data on electoral outcomes, including voter turnout by gender, performance of female candidates, and performance of candidates with criminal records.

  2. Gather data on local instances of political conflict, violent events, and women's political mobilization.

  3. Implement a randomized controlled trial to assess whether providing women with a norms-compatible "use case" for phones can spur deeper adoption, while quantifying how peer effects inform the adoption decision, and how adoption impacts social norms and women's networks.


This work follows the Sanchar Kranti Yojana (SKY), a scheme implemented by the Chhattisgarhi government, which distributed free smartphones to millions of women across the state shortly before state and national elections. As a part of the program, the government also commissioned cell towers to be built in areas with poor network coverage, enabling first-time access to the Internet for low-income rural communities. 


The research team has implemented multiple studies focused on SKY and women’s phone use, as the phones were distributed in communities that often disapprove of women using mobile phones. The first study focused on the political and electoral implications of SKY in rural areas, drawing upon multiple secondary data sources and primary survey data to understand how SKY affected voter turnout, candidate quality, election outcomes, and individuals’ ability to coordinate for collective action. In 2022-23, the research team conducted a primary survey to build on the results of secondary data analysis. The survey covered 13 districts across Chhattisgarh, interviewing over 20,000 men and women, as well as more than 2,700 community leaders. Surveys covered the extent of citizens' political knowledge and engagement, affective polarization, susceptibility to misinformation, and experience with local conflict and protests. The SKY analysis takes advantage of the program’s 1,000-household eligibility cutoff, utilizing a regression discontinuity framework to assess impacts of SKY for locations just above and below the cutoff. As of late 2023, the research team is cleaning, processing and analyzing survey data, and results are forthcoming.


The second study, a randomized control trial conducted in 212 SKY communities, examines the extent to which a norms-compatible phone use case affects longer-term mobile phone use by women in socially conservative areas, and the implications of women’s increased phone use. The use case is known as “Mor Awaaz” (My Voice in Chhattisgarhi), and it was offered after women participated in a 45-minute, group-based, digital literacy training that instructed women on the basics of smartphone use. Mor Awaaz enrollees received weekly calls with pre-recorded educational and entertaining messages related to women’s health and nutrition, among other topics. These women were then surveyed each month on similar topics. Further, the research design allows us to investigate the extent to which women’s phone engagement is affected by their peers’ phone use and by economic incentives. After running Mor Awaaz for several years, the research team collected endline data from approximately 3,800 households in 2022. As of late 2023, more results are forthcoming, but preliminary survey evidence points to the particular value of digital literacy training in increasing women’s phone use, as well as improving their mental wellbeing.
